column4: the actions which the Central Bank has taken in regard to Setanta have been with the aim of protecting the interests of Irish consumers. column5: MFSA.  Setanta sold insurance in Ireland on a freedom of services basis
column6: that is

column8: however
column9: have an administrative office in Blanchardstown.  Setanta was required to comply with conduct of business requirements of the Central Bank when selling to Irish consumers. column12: two thirds of which were commercial motor insurance policies and one third of which were private motor insurance policies.  In January 2014 the MFSA directed Setanta to cease carrying on the business of insurance
column13: including the renewal of existing business. In early September 2013 the Central Bank became concerned about the financial position of Setanta based on market intelligence
column16: on a regulator to regulator basis
column17: seeking confirmation that Setanta was solvent and that it had sufficient assets to meets its liabilities to Irish policyholders.  The MFSA confirmed that it received monthly management accounts and solvency calculations and
column18: according to its latest management accounts

column20: including our concerns about how the company was reserving for its claims. column21: the Central Bank continued to engage very closely with the MFSA following the submission of the report to it. column22: the MFSA appointed a liability loss adjuster firm in December 2013 to carry out an independent assessment of Setanta’s outstanding loss reserves. column23: and its knowledge of Setanta as its prudential regulator

column25: the MFSA continued to engage with Setanta in an attempt to resolve its financial difficulties and ultimately informed the Central Bank on 11 April that Setanta had failed to secure a resolution to its solvency deficit and that the directors were going to propose a voluntary liquidation to its shareholders. column26: Setanta notified its broker network that a solvent run-off of the business was no longer possible and that this information should be brought to the attention of policyholders. column38: the firm and the liquidator. We will continue to ensure affected consumers are fully informed of any developments and to liaise with the MFSA during the liquidation process. I thank the members for their attention.

column4: that was their responsibility.  The Deputy can read the response in their statement.  They are responsible as the supervisory authority
column5: but when our concerns continued
column6: we did not leave the matter there. column7: our concerns were confirmed
column8: but they related to how the claims were being reserved for on individual files
column9: not the firm's solvency position.  We felt it important to refer the matter to the appropriate authority

column11: it was the only one with a full picture of the company.  We had a small window - the small number of claim files - through which to look into the company.

column4: which confirmed our concerns.  Until that point

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	149	The concept of passporting is a logical consequence of the fact that
column2: once authorised in one European Union or EEA member state
column3: a company has been authorised to provide its services throughout the European Union.  I will outline how it works.  We are notified when a company is passporting in to the State.  There is provision for host state regulators to receive periodic information on the volume of business being written in that member state.  However
column4: the responsibility to engage in prudential supervision rests with the home state regulator.  The host state regulator is only responsible for the conduct of business. column5: the regulator must be aware of the full financial position of the company.  The prudential supervisor has visibility in that regard
column6: rather than the conduct of business supervisor.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	151	There are solvency requirements
column2: systems and controls that institutions must have in place to ensure they have the resources to meet their liabilities.  This is set out in a framework known as Solvency I which has been and is being revised at European level.  From January 2016 onwards
column3: we will have Solvency II
column4: a more sophisticated and robust regime that will apply throughout Europe.  We already operate many of its features in the State in respect of the companies we prudentially supervise.  Of particular relevance in this case is the fact that Solvency II will introduce a more codified method of valuation of assets and liabilities throughout Europe and more uniform approaches to actuarial standards and practices. column5: first and foremost
column6: that of the management of the insurance company.  It must get it right.  Clearly
column7: where a company does not
column8: in the first instance
column9: estimate correctly how much money it will need to meet a claim
column11: all of its calculations will come up short.

column1: #PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	211	I wish to pose a final question.  I am of the view that the Central Bank was extremely lax in respect of this matter.  Mr. Sheridan can bat for his own side in a moment in respect of that assertion on my part.  It seems that the only flag that was raised for consumers came in the form of the widely-circulated press release.  On numerous occasions we asked the Minister what he was doing to ensure that customers would not be at a loss as a result of the decision taken in January.  It does not appear that the Central Bank took any serious action to protect customers from having their policies renewed by an institution which the Malta financial services authority had directed to stop renewing them.  Was the Central Bank aware of the fact that policies were being renewed after the 24 January cut-off point?  What action is it taking in respect of the renewal of those policies?  Is the Central Bank of the view that it was appropriate that the policies in question were renewed?  The Irish Brokers Association has referred to a statutory instrument and stated that its members issue renewal notices prior to renewal dates.  This means that if a notice was issued on 23 January last and even though it had been informed that it could not do so from the following day
column2: Setanta still renewed the relevant policy five weeks and six days later.  That is what happened to many people who renewed their policies and paid their premiums in full.  Those people subsequently were without insurance cover
column3: which means that they lost out on the double.  What action has the Central Bank taken - or is it going to take - in respect of that practice?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	212	The Deputy is right.  The Maltese authorities directed the firm to cease writing new business and renewing policies.  They are investigating the fact that policies were sold post 24 January.  We have been in contact with them and they are looking into the matter.  They have committed to sharing the results of their investigation with us.  At this stage we cannot say what happened
column2: how it happened or whether it was at the level of the insurance company.  Obviously
column3: the latter was certainly the case because the company continued to underwrite some business that was going through the pipeline.  The suspension was issued by the Maltese authorities to the company.  The company wrote to all its brokers confirming the suspension and they were all obliged to write to the policyholders to make them aware of it.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	227	I will try to address that.  Under the current regime
column2: the first thing a company has to do is prudently estimate how much money and resources it will need to meet its liabilities on an expected basis
column3: so it takes a prudent approach to what is expected to happen and it sets aside resources to meet that.  We spoke earlier about the inspection we carried out in October and into November
column4: in which we looked at the claims files.  What we noticed on the claims files was that what the claims team was estimating as the amount it might need for the claim seemed low.  That is what we meant when we said earlier that one cannot extrapolate from that into anything else.  How much is held in terms of reserves really depends on a company's prudential assessment of what it thinks its liabilities are going to be.  The solvency margin is then a measure of freely available assets it must maintain over and above that to act as a buffer against unexpected shocks.  If I follow the Deputy's reasoning correctly
column5: one cannot extrapolate from the number of policyholders necessarily or the quantum of reserves that are shown in the statement of affairs as to what the prudential level of reserving should be
column6: because that is something that only the prudential supervisor and the company itself could do with all of the financial information.

I understand what has been said and that we have been to the fore in trying to influence practice
column2: but given what the European markets have been through in the past few years
column3: it is staggering that regulators do not yet interact with each other.  How many other insurance companies like Setanta Insurance are there in Ireland?  I understand most insurance companies here are not Irish owned.  Am I correct in thinking FBD is the only Irish-owned and operated insurance company in the country?  If financial regulators across Europe are not interacting with each other
column4: how many more customers will be impacted on and how many more difficulties will we encounter?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	261	In Ireland we have a large number of Irish-authorised insurance companies
column2: but they do not all do business in Ireland.  In fact
column3: the majority do no business in Ireland.  However
column4: we supervise them prudentially in the same way.  We are also the conduct-of-business supervisor for the firms selling in Ireland.  There is consistency across the market in that regard.  On whether there is another Setanta Insurance
column5: we have a large number of firms - I am not sure of the exact number - that have notified us of their intention to sell different types of insurance policy in Ireland.  However
column6: the number is quite small in the case of motor insurance and these firms are generally not of the size of Setanta Insurance.  Generally
column7: they are in particular categories of insurance in which there would have been one big provider.  I am not really sure how I should answer the question of whether there is another Setanta Insurance.  The European framework is to be and should be applied consistently across countries.  Where it fails is where individual firms do not live up to that standard.  It is up to the supervisors to make sure they do.

column1: #CiaranLynch	unknown-#CiaranLynch-party	unknown-#CiaranLynch-dob	unknown-#CiaranLynch-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	262	Before we move to Deputy Joe Higgins
column2: I seek clarity on a point raised by Deputy Ciara Conway.  Are there cases comparable to what happened in the case of Setanta Insurance or is its case unique?  Is it unique to Ireland or is there a precedent?  Have there been similar collapses in the market?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	263	The Setanta Insurance case is not unique in the sense that there is a large number of companies selling in Ireland the headquarters of which are outside Ireland.  I do not know how many are selling exclusively in Ireland
column2: but I am sure a small number of them are doing so.  On whether it is unique in terms of its failure
column3: it is not because it was supervised by a supervisory authority equivalent to us and licensed by that authority.  I do not make a distinction - I do not believe I can do so - in terms of whether it is supervised by the authorities in the United Kingdom or Malta or wherever else.  It is a difficult question to answer.  About what are we talking precisely?  Is it the model
column4: the European framework or the fact that it was selling only in Ireland?

column1: #CiaranLynch	unknown-#CiaranLynch-party	unknown-#CiaranLynch-dob	unknown-#CiaranLynch-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	264	The question is very simple.  If I was talking to a German
column2: an Austrian or an Italian this afternoon
column3: would he or she say to me that the very same thing happened in his or her country and that another country was involved in terms of the company involved trading out of Cyprus
column4: Lithuania or Ireland?  Therefore
column5: the case would not be unique in the sense that it would have happened previously.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	266	I am not sure about a failure
column2: but it is not unique for a company located in Ireland to only be selling in another country in Europe.

column1: #JoeHiggins	unknown-#JoeHiggins-party	unknown-#JoeHiggins-dob	unknown-#JoeHiggins-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	267	Have the Maltese sent the fraud squad to this company?

column1: #JoeHiggins	unknown-#JoeHiggins-party	unknown-#JoeHiggins-dob	unknown-#JoeHiggins-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	269	Did I hear correctly that the claims submitted so far amounted to approximately €35 million? #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	270	Insurance companies are required to have technical assets - assets of particular acceptability - to cover their expected claims.  Therefore
column2: if it believed it would pay out €35 million in claims
column3: it would have to have at least €35 million in assets to cover them.

column1: #JoeHiggins	unknown-#JoeHiggins-party	unknown-#JoeHiggins-dob	unknown-#JoeHiggins-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	271	Therefore
column2: this company
column3: understanding the business in the way it should
column4: would have had at least €35 million already.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	272	Yes

I presume considerable amounts of money were taken in.  Where did it go?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	279	This is the nub of the question.  Our concern at the beginning was that the firm was under-reserved.  It did not have €35 million because the reserves were smaller than they should have been.

The reserves were a certain amount.  The company had smaller amounts.  I cannot say for sure it ever had the €35 million.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	282	The issue with reserving is that the company was underestimating its liabilities and
column2: therefore
column3: did not hold against those liabilities the assets that it needed to hold.

column2: it took in enough to have the proper reserve.  Is that correct?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	284	Potentially.  I could not say that it did.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	300	I do not know that figure off the top of my head.

column1: #RichardBoydBarrett	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-party	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-dob	unknown-#RichardBoydBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	307	My questions follow those points directly.  Some 75
column2: 000 policyholders have been shafted.  Many of them are small and medium enterprises and many are individuals.  Somebody has failed to see this coming.  If this discussion is to mean anything
column3: we need to learn lessons.  It strikes me that the dogs on the street could have worked out that there was something wrong with a company if it was licensed in Malta although its shareholders were primarily Irish
column4: it was selling exclusively to the Irish market
column5: its main staff operations were in Ireland and
column6: through its name
column7: it packaged itself as Irish.  That is fishy straightaway as far as I am concerned.  I cannot believe somebody in the Central Bank did not figure out much earlier that it was fishy.  Why the hell would a company do that?  There has to be some scam at play.  It is trying to evade regulation
column8: taxation
column9: or both.  Surely that is obvious.  It is absolutely terrifying that the delegates tell me this is happening all over the place in Europe.  There are companies based in Ireland that do not do any business in Ireland.  Why are they here?  What is the reason for their being here?  There are companies selling insurance mainly in Ireland
column11: that are not licensed here.  I had an inquiry from the manager of my son's football team asking why there is such a radical difference between motor insurance premiums offered by various insurance companies.  There are staggering differences
column12: yet the underwriters of the insurance are the same people.  Therefore
column13: there is something fishy going on.  The regulatory regime has failed
column14: both at national and European levels.  Is that not obviously the case?  Must we not seriously ask what went wrong
column15: why we did not spot this and whether there is an endemic problem that could mean there will almost certainly be a recurrence?

None of what occurred would have been an issue had the firm been properly run.  Our concerns were about the reserving.  If the company had been properly run-----

column2: if they all behaved as they should
column3: there would be no need for regulation. The reason the Central Bank is there and we need laws and regulation is that we know there are many in cut-throat
column4: profit-driven
column5: competitive markets
column6: including insurance
column7: who do not play by the rules. There are cowboys left

column10: as Quinn was. Money that should have been applied to provision against losses was being used to leverage other business deals elsewhere. That is what he was doing.

column3: but that is no guarantee.  It is how that is implemented that is key.  I agree with the Deputy that it is down to supervisory authorities to implement that.

If it does not add up that they are licensed in one place and doing all their business here

column1: #PearseDoherty	unknown-#PearseDoherty-party	unknown-#PearseDoherty-dob	unknown-#PearseDoherty-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	336	I suggest that it is something the Central Bank should look into. column2: death and people in very vulnerable situations. Could we not look at a situation - tell me if I am just crackers on this - where the insurance fund pays out 65% of all claims and becomes a creditor of the assets of the company? column3: 000.  Obviously things are structured a certain way
column4: but instead of all this red tape could we not start to act in the interests of citizens - the claimants out there - and introduce legislation
column5: if necessary
column6: to provide that the insurance fund can pay out 65% of all claims where a company goes into liquidation?  While people may get more if there are assets within the company
column7: there would be an up-front payment.  The insurance fund would then recoup whatever it could from the assets of the liquidated company.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-09 00:00:00	Collapse of Setanta Insurance: Central Bank and Department of Finance	337	That is a fair question. column3: there is an absence regarding what the liquidator's position is. We also need to wait for the legal advice and the outcome of that consideration and see what role the fund can play in respect of making the claims. We will reflect on the suggestion made. I am not saying "Yes" or "No". The procedures are not specified
column4: and that is one of the things we will be looking at.

column4: say
column6: even under the existing legislation
